pullRequest.body:
A topology on a module is linear if it is invariant by translation and if there 
is a basis of neighborhoods consisting of submodules.

We are most interested in the case of rings: a topology on a ring is linear 
if it is linear for both the left- and right-module structures on R over itself.
This is equivalent to being invariant by translation and admitting a 
basis of neighborhoods consisting of two-sided ideals.

This will be used in a subsequent PR to evaluate multivariate power series.
We will also show that the natural topology on `MvPowerSeries S R` is a linear topology when `S` has a linear topology (e.g the discrete topology).

Co-authored-by: @mariainesdff and @ADedecker 

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR

Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body: messageFile.md
(Note: we talked about this PR IRL, so I'm marking it as awaiting-author)

Well, I believe I am not ready for the moment to implement this big change, and I would like to go forward with the stuff that is already done and comes after this. So I propose that we leave this interesting refactoring to later work.

@urkud Thanks for your comment. Indeed what we were defining is a special case about linearly topologized modules. I adapted the file to talk about modules.

The only subtlety is that, to check this does indeed give the same thing for non-commutative rings, one needs to start from a basis of left ideals and one of right ideals to build one made of two-sided ideals, which needs a slight trick. I can move this part to a later PR if needed, but I think it also fits here.

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12827097265/job/35768373590)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12827097265/job/35768373870)
I've just had a last look, to me this is ready to go.
I've just had a last look, to me this is ready to go.

```suggestion
it is invariant by translation and admits a basis of neighborhoods of 0 consisting of
```
This doesn't match the lemma's new name, could you fix it?
I would prefer `R` over `alpha`.
We can change that.
Yes but it is not changed? There seem to be several conversations here which were resolved but no action was taken?
I had made the push in the wrong branch
Does this imply that it is a topological ring: i.e. multiplication as bilinear map is continuous?

Yes, but Bourbaki does it the other way round, I believe. In mathlib, we have to start with imposing that we have a topological ring. This is a bit sad, because for `IsLinearTopology.mk_of_twoSidedIdeal`, we could (mathematically) dispose of the hypothesis that we start from a topological ring.
Maybe we could bundle the topological ring hypothesis in the class `IsLinearTopology`.
@ADedecker , what do you think?
Similar to the comment above: is the translation-invariance mentioned above the same as `[TopologicalRing]` here?

Yes, replacing `[TopologicalRing ]` by `[ContinuousConstSMul  ]` would give (mathematically) the same definition. However:
- I've essentially proved that in #18437 (well I need to add the `TwoSidedIdeal` version of `IsRingBasis.mk_of_ideals_of_comm`), so I don't think there's much sense redoing the work here instead of waiting for it to arrive.
- Even when we have these tools, I'm not sure we want the typeclass system to spend too much time synthesizing `TopologicalRing` instances. I would prefer that, in concrete cases, we just prove `TopologicalRing` first (using the special criterion), and then `LinearTopology`.

Thanks for clarifying!

In that case I completely agree with the design choice to assume `[TopologicalRing]`. But please point this out. E.g. in a `## Todo` that points to your wip.
I have made a small modification: `LinearTopology` doesn't assume `TopologicalRing` anymore. The assumption is only added for those lemmas that require it. I have also added a note.

Sorry I'm a bit lost on what you did exactly (it seems that you have not pushed your modifications yet).

What I was suggesting was to *keep* the `TopologicalRing` assumption, rather than `ContinuousConstSMul` (which is precisely Bourbaki's "invariant by translation"), because we expect users to declare the `TopologicalRing` instance before the `IsLinearTopology` one.

But I'd rather wait to see what you have done exactly so that we are on the same page.
Apart from these two, all other lemmas begin their name with `IsLinearTopology.`. So I would put everything in a namespace, and prepend `_root_.` to these two names.
OK.

```suggestion
  rw [isLinearTopology_iff_hasBasis_twoSidedIdeal]
  apply HasBasis.mk
  intro t
  simp only [mem_nhds_discrete, SetLike.mem_coe, TwoSidedIdeal.zero_mem, true_and]
  constructor
   intro ht
    use 
    change {0}  t
    simp only [Set.singleton_subset_iff, ht]
   rintro J, hJt
    exact hJt J.zero_mem
```

```suggestion
instance [DiscreteTopology R] : IsLinearTopology R :=
  have : HasBasis ( 0 : Filter R) (fun _  True) (fun (_ : Unit)  ( : TwoSidedIdeal R)) := by
    rw [nhds_discrete]
    exact hasBasis_pure _
  .mk_of_twoSidedIdeal this
```
This (ab)uses the fact that ` : TwoSidedIdeal R` coerces exactly to `{0}`.

This does not require `IsLinearTopology`: the whole ring is always a two-sided ideal belonging to any filter. Do you really need this for some reason? If that's in a follow up PR, could you remove it from this one and we'll talk about it later?
For whatever lemma in #15007, Lean wanted that instance. I can remove it for the moment.

I know nothing about this, but [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_topology) defines linear topology in a different context, and it doesn't agree with this definition (it uses left submodules, not two sided ideals). I do not suggest that you change the definition (see start of this comment), but I think that existence of different definitions and some relations between them should be discussed in the module docstring.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: definition of linear topologies
